Guess I should skip work, smoke weed, and listen to Marley. Fuck, I was going to do that anyway.<br/> <a href="http://el_warmachine.codexed.com/2011/05/18/armageddon">El_Warmachine</a></p> <p>If wishes were the answer,<br/> I'd pull down some shooting stars<br/> to captivate behind your eyes<br/> like fireflies in jars.<br/> <A href="http://poetymology.codexed.com/2011/05/18/lullaby-on-the-brink-of-travel">Poetymology</a></p> <p>these letters<br/> held together, <br/> sticky adhesive of<br/> cultural recognition.<br/> assembled like a puzzle <br/> awarding a new <br/> contemporary meaning<br/> to a tired old refrain.<br/> RE – FRAIN<br/> RE – FRAME<br/> make it new again<br/> <a href="http://bellwether.codexed.com/2011/05/18/before">Bellwether</a></p> <p>crisscrossing each surface like the plash of a fishnet--for when there is nothing left to show, there will still be something left to gather up.<br/> <a href="http://confluence.codexed.com/2011/05/13/alderney-stones">Confluence</a></p> <p>It’s not that I depend on these things to write, it’s just that my mind is too busy renormalizing itself to efficiently think in a creatively satisfying way.<br/> <a href="http://octo7.codexed.com/2011/05/17/untitled">Octo7</a></p> <p>I feel bland. false.<br/> <a href="http://clayfui.codexed.com/2011/05/12/kneaded-erasers">Clayfui</a></p> <p>I genuinely thought that by exposing my clumsy ruminations to a blank page (and, to a lesser extent, some small sort of audience), there was the slightest chance it might be one way to help me make sense of it all.<br/> <a href="http://folkjokeopus.codexed.com/2011/05/17/shame-on-me">Folkjokeopus</a></p> <p>This is a placeholder. That's really all I wanted to say.<br/> <a href="http://morsmordre.codexed.com/2011/05/13/a-bookmark">Morsmordre</a></p> <p>I could be (more) melodramatic and say that I'd like to find someone who will always chase me, but I would rather find someone who I never feel like I need to run from. <br/> <a href="http://monsterballads.codexed.com/2011/05/15/wont-you-please-forgive-me">MonsterBallads</a></p> <p>And in church, even though they sing of other things, their prayers still include ships, all those at sea; pilots, lobster-crews, fisherman who have been yanked overboard on a line of creels, whole families lost in sudden squalls only a mile from land.<br/> <a href="http://pine.codexed.com/2011/05/15/cuan-uibhist">Pine</a></p> QFT tag:www.codexed.com,2005:Post/36091 2011-05-11T20:26:55-04:00 2011-05-11T20:26:55-04:00 QFT Wednesday <p>But in the end, just like any Full House episode, I learned a valuable lesson (Complete with poignant orchestral music) in friendship, humility and the problems that come with lying your ass off.<br/> <a href="http://whoregagger.codexed.com/2011/05/11/the-car-pt-1">WhoreGagger</a></p> <p>But most other people felt something I didn't. They feel no shame. I wish it were more socially acceptable to shout random compliments at people. Not just to be on the receiving end, but there have definitely been times when I’ve wanted to say something nice to a stranger and I didn’t because I felt it would be weird. Why is complimenting someone weird when you’re an adult but okay when you’re a child?<br/> <a href="http://disturbedanonymous.codexed.com/2011/04/06/trying-to-turn-this-bottle-into-gold">DisturbedAnonymous</a></p> <p>My b-hole burned neon red.<br/> <a href="http://whoregagger.codexed.com/2011/04/04/the-bad-wiping-incident">WhoreGagger</a></p> <p>I'm kind of here, existing, being a technical writing machine and wishing, deeply, for something more or something else.<br/> <a href="http://ethereal.codexed.com/2011/04/04/off-kilter">Ethereal</a></p> <p>True self sufficiency is admirable, but when we struggle alone, we deny a beautiful aspect of human nature. Exercising compassion towards others is wonderful, but if this is the only way we relate to compassion, then we're missing out. Giving without receiving is like admiring a sculpture from only one side. It's still beautiful, but the experience is incomplete. To fully appreciate the sculpture, it's better to see it from the other side as well.<br/> <a href="http://ashling.codexed.com/2011/04/04/stomped-it">Ashling</a></p> QFT tag:www.codexed.com,2005:Post/35373 2011-03-30T23:05:02-04:00 2011-03-30T23:05:02-04:00 QFT Wednesday <p>I bet you make more of a positive difference in people's lives than you realise.<br/> <a href="http://ashling.codexed.com/2011/03/29/good-people">Ashling</a></p> <p>All is well while its just inside my head.<br/> <a href="http://play_dead.codexed.com/2011/03/29/wishing">Play_Dead</a></p> <p>Love is stupid. Don't let anybody tell you differently. You know marriages? They're stupid too. Boyfriends? Girlfriends? Husbands? Wives? Common Law Marriages? All stupid. The only thing that is more stupider than love, are people who say they are in love. Because love doesn't exist. It's as make believe as my 14 inch cock (Mine is only 13). Love is a fairy tale word in a fairy tale world and everybody but you gets to ride the merry-go-round. Love is where losers go to die loser-y deaths because L-O-V-E is actually a shitty little city in northern Ireland where the local government rips your heart out, places it on a stake and laughs sardonically as you slowly die, cold and alone and heartless with no-one by your side.<br/> <a href="http://whoregagger.codexed.com/2011/03/29/l-o-v-e-is-just-a-shitty-place-in-northern-ireland">WhoreGagger</a></p> <p>But I'm fine. Please write a poem of twenty or fewer lines that begins "My mother never forgave my father ..." Please also use two sentences of five words or fewer, one interrogative, and one quotation of any kind. If possible, use three of the following words "Orpheus," "bellybutton," "periphesence," and "shimmy." They’re humming and buzzing just under the surface of my skin. They’re threatening to burst out of my chest like some alien parasite or else burn up the back of my throat and spill out across everything like that time I vomited off the side of my lofted bed.<br/> <a href="http://caligula.codexed.com/2011/02/23/no-time-to-bleed">Caligula</a></p> QFT tag:www.codexed.com,2005:Post/34372 2011-02-19T14:19:25-05:00 2011-02-19T14:19:25-05:00 Rock 'n Roll Dear Dust,<br/> <br/> Our Official Bonding Moment was in junior year of high school. I don't know why I feel the need to write that in capital letters. It just seems proper. Important, like you always were to me. Anyway, this moment occurred long after you had criticized my sister for her homophobic tendencies, but well before I moved half a continent away. I'd say this was right about the time I was realizing how difficult it would be to say goodbye to you, when that came. <br/> <br/> For the most part, I couldn't pick those last years of school out of a line-up, and that's probably for the best, as they never did me any harm. In contrast, the moments I spent with you stand out, and if I had to finger a specific one as the culprit of my attachment to you, I'd point directly to what I'm about to describe. <br/> <br/> It was one of those casually hot Texas days. It was late in the evening, and we were stuck to my dad's old leather couch. Nothing particularly bad had happened, nor was there a momentous occasion that I can say we were celebrating. We were simply existing as two friends do: easily and semi-eloquently. We'd been through worse days, to be sure, but on this night, I remember being especially exhausted, prone to your soft voice, slurred vowels, hushed tone. I'd probably complained for a good half hour about the heat, my family, and how ready I was to be finished with school. I'm sure I was tiresome. <br/> <br/> But you listened like you cared--or at least understood--and then I stretched, stood up, and walked toward our old television. I swung open the barnwood doors of our entertainment center a bit wider, and put in a CD. It was <i>Fallen</i> by Evanescence. Positioned closely together, we listened to the lilting strands of <i>My Immortal</i>, and I remember thinking, "If the world could slow to a crawl, the wind bunker down to a summered stillness, the cars quiet in the streets, and conversation settle to a lull, I would want it to surround a moment like this." Maybe not so verbosely, but you get the picture. We connected over a band that I'm not sure exists any longer. This is fine with me, as we don't either, at least not in as sure a manner as we used to. I guess we can't, so long as the miles are involved. <br/> <br/> But here's the thing: I still cherish you. I'm not sure how many times I referred to you as my best friend. I'm not even sure if you reciprocated the need or passion that I felt in your presence. In all honesty, that matters even less now than it did then. We were what (and who) we wanted to be, and it suited us well enough that we never questioned it. I'm not one for praying these days, but I still thank God you came around when you did, all sorts of sensitive and wearing your lettermen's jacket, and I still remember the color of your truck and how many times it took us to actually get our goodbyes right--and more than that, finalized.<br/> <br/> I guess that's the way things go. People always say that when you graduate, it changes you forever. That it's the turning point of your life. I fought this with every bit of obstinateness in me, but it seems to have happened anyway. There's got to come a point when you relinquish control to the passage of time. Regardless, I still think of you with an overwhelming amount of fondness--perhaps in an effort to counteract all of the anger I feel at the world for separating us. Truncated phone calls and sparse text messages just don't do your conversational skills justice. <br/> <br/> I'm writing this to remind you (and myself) of how close we really were. How much I loved you and how much I still do. <br/> <br/> Sincerely,<br/> The Wind I Hope You Are Not In unsent-letters tag:www.codexed.com,2005:Post/34352 2011-02-18T02:58:11-05:00 2011-02-18T02:58:11-05:00 Another 7 months My dear You, <br/> <br/> I wrote you a letter about a year ago explaining the impact of what was then our latest encounter. I knew, even as the words left my head, that the letter would be unsent forever. We have known each other for 12 years now. I've seen you once since then, another 7 months ago and thought of you since then almost every day. Every day, except for the ones where I made myself not think of you. Your beauty is beyond reason, your depravity and mental condition are living reminders to me that the best things on earth are flawed and bruised and hurt but so very beautiful all the same. A year ago when I wrote you that letter I hated your fiance, now he's gone. Today I hate the tattoo artist guy you're dating who makes more money than I will likely ever make and takes you on trips to New York, Mexico, maybe Ohio too. When I think of the chances I've been given I feel only a sort of numb and constant regret. 7 months ago you sat on a bench with me at the waterfront. We were half-drunk and I was half in love. Today I know in the deepest part of my self that we will never be and that realistically I am somewhat obsessed with a version of you that does not likely exist. Regardless of that, I eagerly await your next contact. <br/> <br/> Love Always, <br/> <br/> Me unsent-letters tag:www.codexed.com,2005:Post/34332 2011-02-16T23:59:12-05:00 2011-02-16T23:59:12-05:00 QFT Wednesday <p>I want to be fearless.<br/> <a href="http://wanderlust.codexed.com/2011/02/16/a-new-goal-fearlessness-or-impossibility">Wanderlust</a></p> <p>I am waiting for this lightness, for whatever mental wall that holds me back to crumble. <br/> <a href="http://canter.codexed.com/2011/02/13/on-running">Canter</a></p> <p>I am shedding my insecurities. And your laughter, like the ringing of bells, came in great crashing peals that surrounded and drowned me in your mirth. We spoke in libraries and hallways, never for very long, but always at the precisely perfect length: masterfully measured strings of syllables, as though Lachesis herself had deigned to draw us together.<br/> <br/> And here we parted ways for the first time: another man came gallivanting into your life, clumsily took you by the hand, and professed the power of love. Starry-eyed, you went tumbling after him, and so I tipped my hat to you, happy to step back.<br/> <br/> We know how that ended, though: we know the hell and the horror of the speeches that cleaved you from each other. For a time, we drifted, silently separated.<br/> <br/> When we came together again, we were still kept apart: once more you had set yourself to spilling your secrets and surrendering your sex. I watched from a distance, my heart aching: there was still a lilt in your voice that turned my eyes heavenward, a rhythm in your step that I wished to match, and a power in your embrace that I wanted to taste. Yet you were happy, and that was good enough for me: after all, in the end, I am more desirous of your pleasure than mine.<br/> <br/> But something happened. Mistakes were made, and misunderstandings were multiplied. You fell apart in the most terrible of ways. By coincidence, my own endeavors failed simultaneously, and so we were left together: brokenhearted, teary-eyed, desperate to make some sense of things. By sheer power of will I worked to support you when I could barely support myself. Oh, Lucrezia, I remember the nights you cried: each of them I recall so vividly because the tears in my own eyes so often made the way forward difficult to see, and we could only assume that we lived in an everlasting purgatorial pain.<br/> <br/> In the darkness, we could see the first flickers of a flame between us.<br/> <br/> It took time--so much time, because there was such confusion and pain in our hearts. It seems, now, that these things still exist in your heart, and you have let them taint your outlook on life--and your outlook on me.<br/> <br/> We took that first step together: it was by no means an arbitrary decision on my part or yours. I feel that the truth is that we both knew before we began the boundaries we would need to run beside; we both knew what we wanted and how we could obtain that, but somewhere along the way, you seem to have forgotten now.<br/> <br/> Now, Lucrezia, you seem keen to cut me out, as though I were a vile cancer bent on extracting the life from your body. So you have tipped your poison into my drink, and yours was a movement so sweet, so silent, that I drank the substance down without a second thought. I have invested much trust in you, after all.<br/> <br/> I have choked and retched and demanded explanations for this: did you think I was going to take advantage of you? Did you fancy me to be like all those others, who were out to rend your porcelain heart to pretty bits? You would not even give the chance to explain myself before you took action and dispensed your swift and vicious judgmental justice.<br/> <br/> So I will pass on, Lucrezia--I will pass from these sufferings and seek out a peace far greater than your arms ever could have offered me. I wished to give you so much, but you allowed me so little.<br/> <br/> One day, you will know the bite of the poison, too.<br/> <br/> As always, I remain, ineffectually yours,<br/> <br/> The Third unsent-letters tag:www.codexed.com,2005:Post/34063 2011-02-03T19:13:31-05:00 2011-02-03T19:13:31-05:00 QFT Wednesday <p>Crying is healthy.
